verses.text: Therefore I will praise Thee for ever all the days of my life; for all the powers of the heavens do praise Thee, and Thine is the glory for ever and ever, Amen.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:239
verses.text: And the Lord heard his voice, and had compassion upon him.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:240
verses.text: And there appeared a flame of fire about him, and all the iron shackles and chains which were about him fell off; and the Lord healed Manasseh from his affliction, and brought him back to Jerusalem unto his kingdom: and Manasseh knew that the Lord He is God alone.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:241
verses.text: And he worshipped the Lord God alone with all his heart, and with all his soul, all the days of his life; and he was esteemed righteous.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:242
verses.text: And he took away the strange gods and the graven image out of the house of the Lord, and all the altars which he had built in the house of the Lord, and all the altars in Jerusalem, and he cast them out of the city.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:243
verses.text: And he repaired the altar of the Lord, and sacrificed thereon peace-offerings and thank-offerings.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:244
verses.text: And Manasseh spake to Judah to serve the Lord God of Israel.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:245
verses.text: And he slept in peace with his fathers; and Amon his son reigned in his stead.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:246
verses.text: And he did evil in the sight of the Lord according to all things that Manasseh his father had done in the former part of his reign.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:247
verses.text: And he provoked the Lord his God to anger".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:248
verses.text: Ye have heard, our beloved children, how the Lord God for a while punished him that was addicted to idols, and had slain many innocent persons; and yet that He received him when he repented, and forgave him his offences, and restored him to his kingdom.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:249
verses.text: For He not only forgives the penitent, but reinstates them in their former dignity.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:250
verses.text: Amon May be an Example to Such as Sin with an High Hand.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:251
verses.text: XXIII.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:252
verses.text: There is no sin more grievous than idolatry, for it is an impiety against God: and yet even this sin has been forgiven, upon sincere repentance.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:253
verses.text: But if any one sin in direct opposition, and on purpose to try whether God will punish the wicked or not, such a one shall have no remission, although he say with himself, "All is well, and I will walk according to the conversation of my evil heart".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:254
verses.text: Such a one was Amon the son of Manasseh.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:255
verses.text: For the Scripture says: "And Amon reasoned an evil reasoning of transgression, and said, My father from his childhood was a great transgressor, and repented in his old age; and now I will walk as my soul lusteth, and afterwards I will return unto the Lord.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:256
verses.text: And he did evil in the sight of the Lord above all that were before him.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:257
verses.text: And the Lord God soon destroyed him utterly from His good land.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:258
verses.text: And his servants conspired against him, and slew him in his own house, and he reigned two years only".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:259
verses.text: That Christ Jesus Our Lord Came to Save Sinners by Repentance.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:260
verses.text: XXIV.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:261
verses.text: Take heed, therefore, ye of the laity, lest any one of you fix the reasoning of Amon in his heart, and be suddenly cut off, and perish.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:262
verses.text: In the same manner, let the bishop take all the care he can that those which are yet innocent may not fall into sin; and let him heal and receive those which turn from their sins.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:263
verses.text: But if he is pitiless, and will not receive the repenting sinner, he will sin against the Lord his God, pretending to be more just than God's justice, and not receiving him whom He has received, through Christ; for whose sake He sent His Son upon earth to men, as a man; for whose sake God was pleased that He, who was the Maker of man and woman, should be born of a woman; for whose sake He did not spare Him from the cross, from death, and burial, but permitted Him to die, who by nature could not suffer, His beloved Son, God the Word, the Angel of His great council, that he might deliver those from death who were obnoxious to death.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:264
verses.text: Him do those provoke to anger who do not receive the penitent.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:265
verses.text: For He was not ashamed of me, Matthew, who had been formerly a publican; and admitted of Peter, when he had through fear denied Him three times, but had appeased Him by repentance, and had wept bitterly; nay, He made him a shepherd to His own lambs.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:266
verses.text: Moreover, He ordained Paul, our fellow-apostle, to be of a persecutor an apostle, and declared him a chosen vessel, even when he had heaped many mischiefs upon us before, and had blasphemed His sacred name.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:267
verses.text: He says also to another, a woman that was a sinner: "Thy sins, which are many, are forgiven, for thou lovest much".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:268
verses.text: And when the elders had set another woman which had sinned before Him, and had left the sentence to Him, and were gone out, our Lord, the Searcher of the hearts, inquiring of her whether the elders had condemned her, and being answered No, He said unto her: "Go thy way therefore, for neither do I condemn thee".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 3:269
verses.text: This Jesus, O ye bishops, our Saviour, our King, and our God, ought to be set before you as your pattern; and Him you ought to imitate, in being meek, quiet, compassionate, merciful, peaceable, without passion, apt to teach, and diligent to convert, willing to receive and to comfort; no strikers, not soon angry, not injurious, not arrogant, not supercilious, not wine-bibbers, not drunkards, not vainly expensive, not lovers of delicacies, not extravagant, using the gifts of God not as another's, but as their own, as good stewards appointed over them, as those who will be required by God to give an account of the same.

chapters.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:1
verses.text: Sec.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:2
verses.text: IV.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:3
verses.text: —On the Management of the Resources Collected for the Support of the Clergy, and the Relief of the Poor.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:4
verses.text: Let the bishop esteem such food and raiment sufficient as suits necessity and decency.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:5
verses.text: Let him not make use of the Lord's goods as another's, but moderately; "for the labourer is worthy of his reward".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:6
verses.text: Let him not be luxurious in diet, or fond of idle furniture, but contented with so much alone as is necessary for his sustenance.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:7
verses.text: Of First-Fruits and Tithes, and After What Manner the Bishop is Himself to Partake of Them, or to Distribute Them to Others.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:8
verses.text: XXV.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:9
verses.text: Let him use those tenths and first-fruits, which are given according to the command of God, as a man of God; as also let him dispense in a right manner the free-will offerings which are brought in on account of the poor, to the orphans, the widows, the afflicted, and strangers in distress, as having that God for the examiner of his accounts who has committed the disposition to him.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:10
verses.text: Distribute to all those in want with righteousness, and yourselves use the things which belong to the Lord, but do not abuse them; eating of them, but not eating them all up by yourselves: communicate with those that are in want, and thereby show yourselves unblameable before God.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:11
verses.text: For if you shall consume them by yourselves, you will be reproached by God, who says to such unsatiable people, who alone devour all, "Ye eat up the milk, and clothe yourselves with the wool;" and in another passage, "Must you alone live upon the earth"? Upon which account you are commanded in the law, "Thou shalt love thy neighbour as thyself".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:12
verses.text: Now we say these things, not as if you might not partake of the fruits of your labours; for it is written, "Thou shalt not muzzle the mouth of the ox which treadeth out the corn;" but that you should do it with moderation and righteousness.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:13
verses.text: As, therefore, the ox that labours in the threshing-floor without a muzzle eats indeed, but does not eat all up; so do you who labour in the threshing-floor, that is, in the Church of God, eat of the Church: which was also the case of the Levites, who served in the tabernacle of the testimony, which was in all things a type of the Church.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:14
verses.text: Nay, further, its very name implied that that tabernacle was fore-appointed for a testimony of the Church.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:15
verses.text: Here, therefore, the Levites also, who attended upon the tabernacle partook of those things that were offered to God by all the people,—namely, gifts, offerings, and first-fruits, and tithes, and sacrifices, and oblations, without disturbance, they and their wives, and their sons and their daughters.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:16
verses.text: Since their employment was the ministration to the tabernacle, therefore they had not any lot or inheritance in the land among the children of Israel, because the oblations of the people were the lot of Levi, and the inheritance of their tribe.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:17
verses.text: You, therefore, O bishops, are to your people priests and Levites, ministering to the holy tabernacle, the holy Catholic Church; who stand at the altar of the Lord your God, and offer to Him reasonable and unbloody sacrifices through Jesus the great High Priest.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:18
verses.text: You are to the laity prophets, rulers, governors, and kings; the mediators between God and His faithful people, who receive and declare His word, well acquainted with the Scriptures.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:19
verses.text: Ye are the voice of God, and witnesses of His will, who bear the sins of all, and intercede for all; whom, as you have heard, the word severely threatens if you hide the key of knowledge from men, who are liable to perdition if you do not declare His will to the people that are under you; who shall have a certain reward from God, and unspeakable honour and glory, if you duly minister to the holy tabernacle.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:20
verses.text: For as yours is the burden, so you receive as your fruit the supply of food and other necessaries.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:21
verses.text: For you imitate Christ the Lord; and as He "bare the sins of us all upon the tree" at His crucifixion, the innocent for those who deserved punishment, so also you ought to make the sins of the people your own.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:22
verses.text: For concerning our Saviour it is said in Isaiah, "He bears our sins, and is afflicted for us".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:23
verses.text: And again: "He bare the sins of many, and was delivered for our offences".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:24
verses.text: As, therefore, you are patterns for others, so have you Christ for your pattern.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:25
verses.text: As, therefore, He is concerned for all, so be you for the laity under you.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:26
verses.text: For do not thou imagine that the office of a bishop is an easy or light burden.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:27
verses.text: As, therefore, you bear the weight, so have you a right to partake of the fruits before others, and to impart to those that are in want, as being to give an account to Him, who without bias will examine your accounts.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:28
verses.text: For those who attend upon the Church ought to be maintained by the Church, as being priests, Levites, presidents, and ministers of God; as it is written in the book of Numbers concerning the priests: "And the Lord said unto Aaron, Thou, and thy sons, and the house of thy family, shall bear the iniquities of the holy things of priesthood".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:29
verses.text: "Behold, I have given unto you the charge of the first-fruits, from all that are sanctified to me by the children of Israel; I have given them for a reward to thee, and to thy sons after thee, by an ordinance for ever.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:30
verses.text: This shall be yours out of the holy things, out of the oblations, and out of the gifts, and out of all the sacrifices, and out of every trespass-offering, and sin-offerings; and all that they render unto me out of all their holy things, they shall belong to thee, and to thy sons: in the sanctuary shall they eat them".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:31
verses.text: And a little after: "All the first-fruits of the oil, and of the wine, and of the wheat, all which they shall give unto the Lord, to thee have I given them; and all that is first ripe, to thee have I given it, and every devoted thing.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:32
verses.text: Every first-born of man and of beast, clean and unclean, and of sacrifice, with the breast, and the right shoulder, all these appertain to the priests, and to the rest of those belonging to them, even to the Levites".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:33
verses.text: Hear this, you of the laity also, the elect Church of God.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:34
verses.text: For the people were formerly called "the people of God," and "an holy nation".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:35
verses.text: You, therefore, are the holy and sacred "Church of God, enrolled in heaven, a royal priesthood, an holy nation, a peculiar people," a bride adorned for the Lord God, a great Church, a faithful Church.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:36
verses.text: Hear attentively now what was said formerly: oblations and tithes belong to Christ our High Priest, and to those who minister to Him.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:37
verses.text: Tenths of salvation are the first letter of the name of Jesus.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:38
verses.text: Hear, O thou Holy Catholic Church, who hast escaped the ten plagues, and hast received the ten commandments, and hast learned the law, and hast kept the faith, and hast believed in Jesus, and hast known the decad, and hast believed in the iota which is the first letter of the name of Jesus, and art named after His name, and art established, and shinest in the consummation of His glory.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:39
verses.text: Those which were then the sacrifices now are prayers, and intercessions, and thanksgivings.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:40
verses.text: Those which were then first-fruits, and tithes, and offerings, and gifts, now are oblations, which are presented by holy bishops to the Lord God, through Jesus Christ, who has died for them.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:41
verses.text: For these are your high priests, as the presbyters are your priests, and your present deacons instead of your Levites; as are also your readers, your singers, your porters, your deaconesses, your widows, your virgins, and your orphans: but He who is above all these is the High Priest.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:42
verses.text: According to What Patterns and Dignity Every Order of the Clergy is Appointed by God.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:43
verses.text: XXVI.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:44
verses.text: The bishop, he is the minister of the word, the keeper of knowledge, the mediator between God and you in the several parts of your divine worship.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:45
verses.text: He is the teacher of piety; and, next after God, he is your father, who has begotten you again to the adoption of sons by water and the Spirit.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:46
verses.text: He is your ruler and governor; he is your king and potentate; he is, next after God, your earthly god, who has a right to be honoured by you.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:47
verses.text: For concerning him, and such as he, it is that God pronounces, "I have said, Ye are gods; and ye are all children of the Most High".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:48
verses.text: And, "Ye shall not speak evil of the gods".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:49
verses.text: For let the bishop preside over you as one honoured with the authority of God, which he is to exercise over the clergy, and by which he is to govern all the people.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:50
verses.text: But let the deacon minister to him, as Christ does to His Father; and let him serve him unblameably in all things, as Christ does nothing of Himself, but does always those things that please His Father.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:51
verses.text: Let also the deaconess be honoured by you in the place of the Holy Ghost, and not do or say anything without the deacon; as neither does the Comforter say or do anything of Himself, but gives glory to Christ by waiting for His pleasure.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:52
verses.text: And as we cannot believe on Christ without the teaching of the Spirit, so let not any woman address herself to the deacon or bishop without the deaconess.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:53
verses.text: Let the presbyters be esteemed by you to represent us the apostles, and let them be the teachers of divine knowledge; since our Lord, when He sent us, said, "Go ye, and make disciples of all nations, baptizing them in the name of the Father, and of the Son, and of the Holy Ghost: teaching them to observe all things whatsoever I have commanded you".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:54
verses.text: Let the widows and orphans be esteemed as representing the altar of burnt-offering; and let the virgins be honoured as representing the altar of incense, and the incense itself.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:55
verses.text: That It is a Horrible Thing for a Man to Thrust Himself into Any Sacerdotal Office, as Did Corah and His Company, Saul and Uzziah.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:56
verses.text: XXVII.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:57
verses.text: As, therefore, it was not lawful for one of another tribe, that was not a Levite, to offer anything, or to approach the altar without the priest, so also do you do nothing without the bishop; for if any one does anything without the bishop, he does it to no purpose.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:58
verses.text: For it will not be esteemed as of any avail to him.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:59
verses.text: For as Saul, when he had offered without Samuel, was told, "It will not avail for thee;" so every person among the laity, doing anything without the priest, labours in vain.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:60
verses.text: And as Uzziah the king, who was not a priest, and yet would exercise the functions of the priests, was smitten with leprosy for his transgression; so every lay person shall not be unpunished who despises God, and is so mad as to affront His priests, and unjustly to snatch that honour to himself: not imitating Christ, "who glorified not Himself to be made an high priest;" but waited till He heard from His Father, "The Lord sware, and will not repent, Thou art a priest for ever, after the order of Melchizedek".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:61
verses.text: If, therefore, Christ did not glorify Himself without the Father, how dare any man thrust himself into the priesthood who has not received that dignity from his superior, and do such things which it is lawful only for the priests to do? Were not the followers of Corah, even though they were of the tribe of Levi, consumed with fire, because they rose up against Moses and Aaron, and meddled with such things as did not belong to them? And Dathan and Abiram went down quick into hell; and the rod that budded put a stop to the readiness of the multitude, and demonstrated who was the high priest ordained by God.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:62
verses.text: You ought therefore, brethren, to bring your sacrifices and your oblations to the bishop, as to your high priest, either by yourselves or by the deacons; and do you bring not those only, but also your first-fruits, and your tithes, and your free-will offerings to him.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:63
verses.text: For he knows who they are that are in affliction, and gives to every one as is convenient, that so one may not receive alms twice or oftener the same day, or the same week, while another has nothing at all.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:64
verses.text: For it is reasonable rather to supply the wants of those who really are in distress, than of those who only appear to be so.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:65
verses.text: Of an Entertainment, and After What Manner Each Distinct Order of the Clergy is to Be Treated by Those Who Invite Them to It.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:66
verses.text: XXVIII.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:67
verses.text: If any determine to invite elder women to an entertainment of love, or a feast, as our Saviour calls it, let them most frequently send to such a one whom the deacons know to be in distress.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:68
verses.text: But let what is the pastor's due, I mean the first-fruits, be set apart in the feast for him, even though he be not at the entertainment, as being your priest, and in honour of that God who has entrusted him with the priesthood.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:69
verses.text: But as much as is given to every one of the elder women, let double so much be given to the deacons, in honour of Christ.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:70
verses.text: Let also a double portion be set apart for the presbyters, as for such who labour continually about the word and doctrine, upon the account of the apostles of our Lord, whose place they sustain, as the counsellors of the bishop and the crown of the Church.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:71
verses.text: For they are the Sanhedrim and senate of the Church.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:72
verses.text: If there be a reader there, let him receive a single portion, in honour of the prophets, and let the singer and the porter have as much.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:73
verses.text: Let the laity, therefore, pay proper honours in their presents, and utmost marks of respect to each distinct order.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:74
verses.text: But let them not on all occasions trouble their governor, but let them signify their desires by those who minister to him, that is, by the deacons, with whom they may be more free.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:75
verses.text: For neither may we address ourselves to Almighty God, but only by Christ.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:76
verses.text: In the same manner, therefore, let the laity make known all their desires to the bishop by the deacon, and accordingly let them act as he shall direct them.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:77
verses.text: For there was no holy thing offered or done in the temple formerly without the priest.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:78
verses.text: "For the priest's lips shall keep knowledge, and they shall seek the law at his mouth," as the prophet somewhere says, "for he is the messenger of the Lord Almighty".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:79
verses.text: For if the worshippers of demons, in their hateful, abominable, and impure performances, imitate the sacred rules till this very day (it is a wide comparison indeed, and there is a vast distance between their abominations and God's sacred worship), in their mockeries of worship they neither offer nor do anything without their pretended priest, but esteem him as the very mouth of their idols of stone, waiting to see what commands he will lay upon them.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:80
verses.text: And whatsoever he commands them, that they do, and without him they do nothing; and they honour him, their pretended priest, and esteem his name as venerable in honour of lifeless statues, and in order to the worship of wicked spirits.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:81
verses.text: If these heathens, therefore, who give glory to lying vanities, and place their hope upon nothing that is firm, endeavour to imitate the sacred rules, how much more reasonable is it that you, who have a most certain faith and undoubted hope, and who expect glorious, and eternal, and never-failing promises, should honour the Lord God in those set over you, and esteem your bishop to be the mouth of God!  What is the Dignity of a Bishop and of a Deacon.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:82
verses.text: XXIX.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:83
verses.text: For if Aaron, because he declared to Pharaoh the words of God from Moses, is called a prophet; and Moses himself is called a god to Pharaoh, on account of his being at once a king and a high priest, as God says to him, "I have made thee a god to Pharaoh, and Aaron thy brother shall be thy prophet;" why do not ye also esteem the mediators of the word to be prophets, and reverence them as gods?  After What Manner the Laity are to Be Obedient to the Deacon.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:84
verses.text: XXX.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:85
verses.text: For now the deacon is to you Aaron, and the bishop Moses.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:86
verses.text: If, therefore, Moses was called a god by the Lord, let the bishop be honoured among you as a god, and the deacon as his prophet.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:87
verses.text: For as Christ does nothing without His Father, so neither does the deacon do anything without his bishop; and as the Son without His Father is nothing, so is the deacon nothing without his bishop; and as the Son is subject to His Father, so is every deacon subject to his bishop; and as the Son is the messenger and prophet of the Father, so is the deacon the messenger and prophet of his bishop.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:88
verses.text: Wherefore let all things that he is to do with any one be made known to the bishop, and be finally ordered by him.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:89
verses.text: That the Deacon Must Not Do Anything Without the Bishop.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:90
verses.text: XXXI.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:91
verses.text: Let him not do anything at all without his bishop, nor give anything without his consent.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:92
verses.text: For if he gives to any one as to a person in distress without the bishop's knowledge, he gives it so that it must tend to the reproach of the bishop, and he accuses him as careless of the distressed.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:93
verses.text: But he that casts reproach on his bishop, either by word or deed, opposes God, not hearkening to what He says: "Thou shalt not speak evil of the gods".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:94
verses.text: For He did not make that law concerning deities of wood and of stone, which are abominable, because they are falsely called gods, but concerning the priests and the judges, to whom He also said, "Ye are gods, and children of the Most High".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:95
verses.text: That the Deacon Must Not Make Any Distributions Without the Consent of the Bishop, Because that Will Turn to the Reproach of the Bishop.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:96
verses.text: XXXII.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:97
verses.text: If therefore, O deacon, thou knowest any one to be in distress, put the bishop in mind of him, and so give to him; but do nothing in a clandestine way, so as may tend to his reproach, lest thou raise a murmur against him; for the murmur will not be against him, but against the Lord God: and the deacon, with the rest, will hear what Aaron and Miriam heard, when they spake against Moses: "How is it that ye were not afraid to speak against my servant Moses?" And again, Moses says to those who rose up against him: "Your murmuring is not against us, but against the Lord our God".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:98
verses.text: For if he that calls one of the laity Raka, or fool, shall not be unpunished, as doing injury to the name of Christ, how dare any man speak against his bishop, by whom the Lord gave the Holy Spirit among you upon the laying on of his hands, by whom ye have learned the sacred doctrines, and have known God, and have believed in Christ, by whom ye were known of God, by whom ye were sealed with the oil of gladness and the ointment of understanding, by whom ye were declared to be the children of light, by whom the Lord in your illumination testified by the imposition of the bishop's hands, and sent out His sacred voice upon every one of you, saying, "Thou art my son, this day have I begotten thee?" By thy bishop, O man, God adopts thee for His child.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:99
verses.text: Acknowledge, O son, that right hand which was a mother to thee.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:100
verses.text: Love him who, after God, is become a father to thee, and honour him.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:101
verses.text: After What Manner the Bishops are to Be Honoured, and to Be Reverenced as Our Spiritual Parents.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:102
verses.text: XXXIII.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:103
verses.text: For if the divine oracle says, concerning our parents according to the flesh, "Honour thy father and thy mother, that it may be well with thee;" and, "He that curseth his father or his mother, let him die the death;" how much more should the word exhort you to honour your spiritual parents, and to love them as your benefactors and ambassadors with God, who have regenerated you by water, and endued you with the fulness of the Holy Spirit, who have fed you with the word as with milk, who have nourished you with doctrine, who have confirmed you by their admonitions, who have imparted to you the saving body and precious blood of Christ, who have loosed you from your sins, who have made you partakers of the holy and sacred eucharist, who have admitted you to be partakers and fellow-heirs of the promise of God! Reverence these, and honour them with all kinds of honour; for they have obtained from God the power of life and death, in their judging of sinners, and condemning them to the death of eternal fire, as also of loosing returning sinners from their sins, and of restoring them to a new life.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:104
verses.text: That Priests are to Be Preferred Before Rulers and Kings.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:105
verses.text: XXXIV.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:106
verses.text: Account these worthy to be esteemed your rulers and your kings, and bring them tribute as to kings; for by you they and their families ought to be maintained.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:107
verses.text: As Samuel made constitutions for the people concerning a king, in the first book of Kings, and Moses did so concerning priests in Leviticus, so do we also make constitutions for you concerning bishops.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:108
verses.text: For if there the multitude distributed the inferior services in proportion to so great a king, ought not therefore the bishop much more now to receive of you those things which are determined by God for the sustenance of himself and of the rest of the clergy belonging to him? But if we may add somewhat further, let the bishop receive more than the other received of old: for he only managed the affairs of the soldiery, being entrusted with war and peace for the preservation of men's bodies; but the other is entrusted with the exercise of the priestly office in relation to God, in order to preserve both body and soul from dangers.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:109
verses.text: By how much, therefore, the soul is more valuable than the body, so much the priestly office is beyond the kingly.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:110
verses.text: For it binds and looses those that are worthy of punishment or of remission.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:111
verses.text: Wherefore you ought to love the bishop as your father, and fear him as your king, and honour him as your lord, bringing to him your fruits and the works of your hands, for a blessing upon you, giving to him your first-fruits, and your tithes, and your oblations, and your gifts, as to the priest of God; the first-fruits of your wheat, and wine, and oil, and autumnal fruits, and wool, and all things which the Lord God gives thee.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:112
verses.text: And thy offering shall be accepted as a savour of a sweet smell to the Lord thy God; and the Lord will bless the works of thy hands, and will multiply the good things of the land.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:113
verses.text: "For a blessing is upon the head of him that giveth".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:114
verses.text: That Both the Law and the Gospel Prescribe Offerings.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:115
verses.text: XXXV.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:116
verses.text: Now you ought to know, that although the Lord has delivered you from the additional bonds, and has brought you out of them to your refreshment, and does not permit you to sacrifice irrational creatures for sin-offerings, and purifications, and scapegoats, and continual washings and sprinklings, yet has He nowhere freed you from those oblations which you owe to the priests, nor from doing good to the poor.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:117
verses.text: For the Lord says to you in the Gospel: "Unless your righteousness abound more than that of the scribes and Pharisees, ye shall by no means enter into the kingdom of heaven".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:118
verses.text: Now herein will your righteousness exceed theirs, if you take greater care of the priests, the orphans, and the widows; as it is written: "He hath scattered abroad; he hath given to the poor; his righteousness remaineth for ever".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:119
verses.text: And again: "By acts of righteousness and faith iniquities are purged".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:120
verses.text: And again: "Every bountiful soul is blessed".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:121
verses.text: So therefore shalt thou do as the Lord has appointed, and shalt give to the priest what things are due to him, the first-fruits of thy floor, and of thy wine-press, and sin-offerings, as to the mediator between God and such as stand in need of purgation and forgiveness.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:122
verses.text: For it is thy duty to give, and his to administer, as being the administrator and disposer of ecclesiastical affairs.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:123
verses.text: Yet shalt thou not call thy bishop to account, nor watch his administration, how he does it, when, or to whom, or where, or whether he do it well or ill, or indifferently; for he has One who will call him to an account, the Lord God, who put this administration into his hands, and thought him worthy of the priesthood of so great dignity.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:124
verses.text: The Recital of the Ten Commandments, and After What Manner They Do Here Prescribe to Us.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:125
verses.text: XXXVI.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:126
verses.text: Have before thine eyes the fear of God, and always remember the ten commandments of God,—to love the one and only Lord God with all thy strength; to give no heed to idols, or any other beings, as being lifeless gods, or irrational beings or daemons.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:127
verses.text: Consider the manifold workmanship of God, which received its beginning through Christ.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:128
verses.text: Thou shalt observe the Sabbath, on account of Him who ceased from His work of creation, but ceased not from His work of providence: it is a rest for meditation of the law, not for idleness of the hands.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:129
verses.text: Reject every unlawful lust, everything destructive to men, and all anger.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:130
verses.text: Honour thy parents, as the authors of thy being.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:131
verses.text: Love thy neighbour as thyself.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:132
verses.text: Communicate the necessaries of life to the needy.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:133
verses.text: Avoid swearing falsely, and swearing often, and in vain; for thou shalt not be held guiltless.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:134
verses.text: Do not appear before the priests empty, and offer thy free-will offerings continually.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:135
verses.text: Moreover, do not leave the church of Christ; but go thither in the morning before all thy work, and again meet there in the evening, to return thanks to God that He has preserved thy life.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:136
verses.text: Be diligent, and constant, and laborious in thy calling.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:137
verses.text: Offer to the Lord thy free-will offerings; for says He, "Honour the Lord with the fruit of thy honest labours".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:138
verses.text: If thou art not able to cast anything considerable into the Corban, yet at least bestow upon the strangers one, or two, or five mites.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:139
verses.text: "Lay up to thyself heavenly treasure, which neither the moth nor thieves can destroy".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:140
verses.text: And in doing this, do not judge thy bishop, or any of thy neighbours among the laity; for if thou judge thy brother, thou becomest a judge, without being constituted such by anybody, for the priests are only entrusted with the power of judging.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:141
verses.text: For to them it is said, "Judge righteous judgment;" and again "Approve yourselves to be exact money-changers".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 4:142
verses.text: For to you this is not entrusted; for, on the contrary, it is said to those who are not of the dignity of magistrates or ministers: "Judge not, and ye shall not be judged".

chapters.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:1
verses.text: Sec.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:2
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:3
verses.text: —On Accusations, and the Treatment of Accusers.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:4
verses.text: Concerning Accusers and False Accusers, and How a Judge is Not Rashly Either to Believe Them or Disbelieve Them, But After an Accurate Examination.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:5
verses.text: XXXVII.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:6
verses.text: But it is the duty of the bishop to judge rightly, as it is written, "Judge righteous judgment;" and elsewhere, "Why do ye not even of yourselves judge what is right?" Be ye therefore as skilful dealers in money: for as these reject bad money, but take to themselves what is current, in the same manner it is the bishops's duty to retain the unblameable, but either to heal, or, if they be past cure, to cast off those that are blameworthy, so as not to be hasty in cutting off, nor to believe all accusations; for it sometimes happens that some, either through passion or envy, do insist on a false accusation against a brother, as did the two elders in the case of Susanna in Babylon, and the Egyptian woman in the case of Joseph.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:7
verses.text: Do thou therefore, as a man of God, not rashly receive such accusations, lest thou take away the innocent and slay the righteous; for he that will receive such accusations is the author of anger rather than of peace.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:8
verses.text: But where there is anger, there the Lord is not; for that anger, which is the friend of Satan—I mean that which is excited unjustly by the means of false brethren—never suffers unanimity to be in the Church.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:9
verses.text: Wherefore, when you know such persons to be foolish, quarrelsome, passionate, and such as delight in mischief, do not give credit to them; but observe such as they are, when you hear anything from them against their brother: for murder is nothing in their eyes, and they cast a man down in such a way as one would not suspect.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:10
verses.text: Do thou therefore consider diligently the accuser, wisely observing his mode of life, what, and of what sort it is; and in case thou findest him a man of veracity, do according to the doctrine of our Lord, and taking him who is accused, rebuke him, that he may repent, when nobody is by.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:11
verses.text: But if he be not persuaded, take with thee out or two more, and so show him his fault, and admonish him with mildness and instruction; for "wisdom will rest upon an heart that is good, but is not understood in the heart of the foolish".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:12
verses.text: That Sinners are Privately to Be Reproved, and the Penitent to Be Received, According to the Constitution of Our Lord.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:13
verses.text: XXXVIII.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:14
verses.text: If, therefore, he be persuaded by the mouth of you three, it is well.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:15
verses.text: But if any one hardens himself, "tell it to the Church: but if he neglects to hear the Church, let him be to thee as an heathen man and a publican;" and receive him no longer into the Church as a Christian, but reject him as an heathen.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:16
verses.text: But if he be willing to repent, receive him.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:17
verses.text: For the Church does not receive an heathen or a publican to communion, before they every one repent of their former impieties; for our Lord Jesus, the Christ of God, has appointed place for the acceptance of men upon their repentance.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:18
verses.text: Examples of Repentance.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:19
verses.text: XXXIX.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:20
verses.text: For I Matthew, one of those twelve which speak to you in this doctrine, am an apostle, having myself been formerly a publican, but now have obtained mercy through believing, and have repented of my former practices, and have been vouchsafed the honour to be an apostle and preacher of the word.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:21
verses.text: And Zacchaeus, whom the Lord received upon his repentance and prayers to Him, was also himself in the same manner a publican at first.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:22
verses.text: And, besides, even the soldiers and multitude of publicans, who came to hear the word of the Lord about repentance, heard this from the prophet John, after he had baptized them: "Do nothing more than that which is appointed you".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:23
verses.text: In like manner, life is not refused to the heathen, if they repent and cast away their unbelief.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:24
verses.text: Esteem, therefore, every one that is convicted of any wicked action, and has not repented, as a publican or an heathen.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:25
verses.text: But if he afterward repents, and turns from his error, then, as we receive the heathen, when they wish to repent, into the Church indeed to hear the word, but do not receive them to communion until they have received the seal of baptism, and are made complete Christians; so do we also permit such as these to enter only to hear, until they show the fruit of repentance, that by hearing the word they may not utterly and irrecoverably perish.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:26
verses.text: But let them not be admitted to communion in prayer; and let them depart after the reading of the law, and the prophets, and the Gospel, that by such departure they may be made better in their course of life, by endeavouring to meet every day about the public assemblies, and to be frequent in prayer, that they also may be at length admitted, and that those who behold them may be affected, and be more secured by fearing to fall into the same condition.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:27
verses.text: That We are Not to Be Implacable to Him Who Has Once or Twice Offended.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:28
verses.text: XL.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:29
verses.text: But yet do not thou, O bishop, presently abhor any person who has fallen into one or two offences, nor shalt thou exclude him from the word of the Lord, nor reject him from common intercourse, since neither did the Lord refuse to eat with publicans and sinners; and when He was accused by the Pharisees on this account, He said: "They that are well have no need of the physician, but they that are sick".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:30
verses.text: Do you, therefore, live and dwell with those who are separated from you for their sins; and take care of them, comforting them, and confirming them, and saying to them: "Be strengthened, ye weak hands and feeble knees".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:31
verses.text: For we ought to comfort those that mourn, and afford encouragement to the fainthearted, lest by immoderate sorrow they degenerate into distraction, since "he that is fainthearted is exceedingly distracted".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:32
verses.text: After What Manner We Ought to Receive a Penitent; How We Ought to Deal with Offenders, and When They are to Be Cut Off from the Church.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:33
verses.text: XLI.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:34
verses.text: But if any one returns, and shows forth the fruit of repentance, then do ye receive him to prayer, as the lost son, the prodigal, who had consumed his father's substance with harlots, who fed swine, and desired to be fed with husks, and could not obtain it.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:35
verses.text: This son, when he repented, and returned to his father, and said, "I have sinned against Heaven, and before thee, and am no more worthy to be called thy son;" the father, full of affection to his child, received him with music, and restored him his old robe, and ring, and shoes, and slew the fatted calf, and made merry with his friends.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:36
verses.text: Do thou therefore, O bishop, act in the same manner.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:37
verses.text: And as thou receivest an heathen after thou hast instructed and baptized him, so do thou let all join in prayers for this man, and restore him by imposition of hands to his ancient place among the flock, as one purified by repentance; and that imposition of hands shall be to him instead of baptism: for by the laying on of our hands the Holy Ghost was given to believers.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:38
verses.text: And in case some one of those brethren who had stood immoveable accuse thee, because thou art reconciled to him, say to him: "Thou art always with me, and all that I have is thine.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:39
verses.text: It was meet to make merry and be glad: for this thy brother was dead, and is alive again; he was lost, and is found".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:40
verses.text: For that God does not only receive the penitent, but restores them to their former dignity, holy David is a sufficient witness, who, after his sin in the matter of Uriah, prayed to God, and said: "Restore unto me the joy of Thy salvation, and uphold me with Thy free Spirit".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:41
verses.text: And again: "Turn Thy face from my sins, and blot out all mine offences.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:42
verses.text: Create in me a clean heart, O God, and renew a right spirit in my inward parts.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:43
verses.text: Cast me not away from Thy presence, and take not Thy Holy Spirit from me".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:44
verses.text: Do thou therefore, as a compassionate physician, heal all that have sinned, making use of saving methods of cure; not only cutting and searing, or using corrosives, but binding up, and putting in tents, and using gentle healing medicines, and sprinkling comfortable words.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:45
verses.text: If it be an hollow wound, or great gash, nourish it with a suitable plaister, that it may be filled up, and become even with the rest of the whole flesh.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:46
verses.text: If it be foul, cleanse it with corrosive powder, that is, with the words of reproof.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:47
verses.text: If it have proud flesh, eat it down with a sharp plaister—the threats of judgment.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:48
verses.text: If it spreads further, sear it, and cut off the putrid flesh, mortifying him with fastings.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:49
verses.text: But if, after all that thou hast done, thou perceivest that from the feet to the head there is no room for a fomentation, or oil, or bandage, but that the malady spreads and prevents all cure, as a gangrene which corrupts the entire member; then, with a great deal of consideration, and the advice of other skilful physicians, cut off the putrefied member, that the whole body of the Church be not corrupted.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:50
verses.text: Be not therefore ready and hasty to cut off, nor do thou easily have recourse to the saw, with its many teeth; but first use a lancet to lay open the wound, that the inward cause whence the pain is derived being drawn out, may keep the body free from pain.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:51
verses.text: But if thou seest any one past repentance, and he is become insensible, then cut off the incurable from the Church with sorrow and lamentation.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:52
verses.text: For: "Take out from among yourselves that wicked person".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:53
verses.text: And: "Ye shall make the children of Israel to fear".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:54
verses.text: And again: "Thou shalt not accept the persons of the rich in judgment".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:55
verses.text: And: "Thou shalt not pity a poor man in his cause: for the judgment is the Lord's".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:56
verses.text: That a Judge Must Not Be a Respecter of Persons.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:57
verses.text: XLII.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:58
verses.text: But if the slanderous accusation be false, and you that are the pastors, with the deacons, admit of that falsehood for truth, either by acceptance of persons or receiving of bribes, as willing to do that which will he pleasing to the devil, and so you thrust out from the Church him that is accused, but is clear of the crime, you shall give an account in the day of the Lord.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:59
verses.text: For it is written: "The innocent and the righteous thou shalt not slay".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:60
verses.text: "Thou shalt not take gifts to smite the soul: for gifts blind the eyes of the wise, and destroy the words of the righteous".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:61
verses.text: And again: "They that justify the wicked for gifts, and take away the righteousness of the righteous from him".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:62
verses.text: Be careful, therefore, not to condemn any persons unjustly, and so to assist the wicked.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:63
verses.text: For "woe to him that calls evil good, and good evil; bitter sweet, and sweet bitter; that puts light for darkness, and darkness for light".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:64
verses.text: Take care, therefore, lest by any means ye become acceptors of persons, and thereby fall under this voice of the Lord.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:65
verses.text: For if you condemn others unjustly, you pass sentence against yourselves.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:66
verses.text: For the Lord says: "With what judgment ye judge, ye shall be judged; and as you condemn, you shall be condemned".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:67
verses.text: If, therefore, ye judge without respect of persons, ye will discover that accuser who bears false witness against his neighbour, and will prove him to be a sycophant, a spiteful person, and a murderer, causing perplexity by accusing the man as if he were wicked, inconstant in his words, contradicting himself in what he affirms, and entangled with the words of his own mouth; for his own lips are a dangerous snare to him: whom, when thou hast convicted him of speaking falsely, thou shalt judge severely, and shalt deliver him to the fiery sword, and thou shalt do to him as he wickedly proposed to do to his brother; for as much as in him lay he slew his brother, by forestalling the ears of the judge.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:68
verses.text: Now it is written, that "he that sheddeth man's blood, for that his own blood shall be shed".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:69
verses.text: And: "Thou shalt take away that innocent blood, which was shed without cause, from thee".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:70
verses.text: After What Manner False Accusers are to Be Punished.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:71
verses.text: XLIII.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:72
verses.text: Thou shalt therefore cast him out of the congregation as a murderer of his brother.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:73
verses.text: Some time afterwards, if he says that he repents, mortify him with fastings, and afterwards ye shall lay your hands upon him and receive him, but still securing him, that he does not disturb anybody a second time.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:74
verses.text: But if, when he is admitted again, he be alike troublesome, and will not cease to disturb and to quarrel with his brother, spying faults out of a contentious spirit, cast him out as a pernicious person, that he may not lay waste the Church of God.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:75
verses.text: For such a one is the raiser of disturbances in cities; for he, though he be within, does not become the Church, but is a superfluous and vain member, casting a blot, as far as in him lies, on the body of Christ.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:76
verses.text: For if such men as are born with superfluous members of their body, which hang to them as fingers, or excrescences of flesh, cut them away from themselves on account of their indecency, whereby the unseemliness vanishes, and the man recovers his natural good shape by the means of the surgeon; how much more ought you, the pastors of the Church (for the Church is a perfect body, and sound members; of such as believe in God, in the fear of the Lord, and in love), to do the like when there is found in it a superfluous member with wicked designs, and rendering the rest of the body unseemly, and disturbing it with sedition, and war, and evil-speaking; causing fears, disturbances, blots, evil-speaking, accusations, disorders, and doing the like works of the devil, as if he were ordained by the devil to cast a reproach on the Church by calumnies, and mighty disorders, and strife, and division! Such a one, therefore, when he is a second time cast out of the Church, is justly cut off entirely from the congregation of the Lord.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:77
verses.text: And now the Church of the Lord will be more beautiful than it was before, when it had a superfluous, and to itself a disagreeable member.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 5:78
verses.text: Wherefore henceforward it will be free from blame and reproach, and become clear of such wicked, deceitful, abusive, unmerciful, traitorous persons; of such as are "haters of those that are good, lovers of pleasure," affecters of vainglory, deceivers, and pretenders to wisdom; of such as make it their business to scatter, or rather utterly to disperse, the lambs of the Lord.

chapters.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:1
verses.text: Sec.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:2
verses.text: VI.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:3
verses.text: —The Disputes of the Faithful to Be Settled by the Decisions of the Bishop, and the Faithful to Be Reconciled.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:4
verses.text: Do thou therefore, O bishop, together with thy subordinate clergy, endeavour rightly to divide the word of truth.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:5
verses.text: For the Lord says: "If you walk cross-grained to me, I will walk cross-grained to you".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:6
verses.text: And elsewhere: "With the holy Thou wilt be holy, and with the perfect man Thou wilt be perfect, and with the froward Thou wilt be froward".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:7
verses.text: Walk therefore holily, that you may rather appear worthy of praise from the Lord than of complaint from the adversary.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:8
verses.text: That the Deacon is to Ease the Burden of the Bishops, and to Order the Smaller Matters Himself.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:9
verses.text: XLIV.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:10
verses.text: Be ye of one mind, O ye bishops, one with another, and be at peace with one another; sympathize with one another, love the brethren, and feed the people with care; with one consent teach those that are under you to be of the same sentiments and to be of the same opinions about the same matters, "that there may be no schisms among you; that ye may be one body and one spirit, perfectly joined together in the same mind and in the same judgment," according to the appointment of the Lord.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:11
verses.text: And let the deacon refer all things to the bishop, as Christ does to His Father.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:12
verses.text: But let him order such things as he is able by himself, receiving power from the bishop, as the Lord did from His Father the power of creation and of providence.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:13
verses.text: But the weighty matters let the bishop judge; but let the deacon be the bishop's ear, and eye, and mouth, and heart, and soul, that the bishop may not be distracted with many cares, but with such only as are more considerable, as Jethro did appoint for Moses, and his counsel was received.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:14
verses.text: That Contentions and Quarrels are Unbecoming Christians.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:15
verses.text: XLV.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:16
verses.text: It is therefore a noble encomium for a Christian to have no contest with any one; but if by any management or temptation a contest arises with any one, let him endeavour that it may be composed, though thereby he be obliged to lose somewhat; and let it not come before an heathen tribunal.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:17
verses.text: Nay, indeed, you are not to permit that the rulers of this world should pass sentence against your people; for by them the devil contrives mischief to the servants of God, and occasions a reproach to be cast upon us, as though we had not "one wise man that is able to judge between his brethren," or to decide their controversies.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:18
verses.text: That Believers Ought Not to Go to Law Before Unbelievers; Nor Ought Any Unbeliever to Be Called for a Witness Against Believers.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:19
verses.text: XLVI.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:20
verses.text: Let not the heathen therefore know of your differences among one another, nor do you receive unbelievers as witnesses against yourselves, nor be judged by them, nor owe them anything on account of tribute or fear; but "render to Caesar the things that are Caesar's, and unto God the things that are God's," as tribute, taxes, or poll-money, as our Lord by giving a piece of money was freed from disturbance.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:21
verses.text: Choose therefore rather to suffer harm, and to endeavour after those things that make for peace, not only among the brethren, but also among the unbelievers.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:22
verses.text: For by suffering loss in the affairs of this life, thou wilt be sure not to suffer in the concerns of piety, and wilt live religiously, and according to the command of Christ.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:23
verses.text: But if brethren have lawsuits one with another, which God forbid, you who are the rulers ought thence to learn that such as these do not do the work of brethren in the Lord, but rather of public enemies; and one of the parties will be found to be mild, gentle, and the child of light; but the other unmerciful, insolent, and covetous.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:24
verses.text: Let him, therefore, who is condemned be rebuked, let him be separated, let him undergo the punishment of his hatred to his brother.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:25
verses.text: Afterwards, when he repents, let him be received; and so, when they have learned prudence, they will ease your judicatures.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:26
verses.text: It is also a duty to forgive each other's trespasses—not the duty of those that judge, but of those that have quarrels; as the Lord determined when I Peter asked Him, "How oft shall my brother sin against me, and I forgive him? Till seven times?" He replied, "I say not unto thee, Until seven times, but until seventy times seven".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:27
verses.text: For so would our Lord have us to be truly His disciples, and never to have anything against anybody; as, for instance, anger without measure, passion without mercy, covetousness without justice, hatred without reconciliation.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:28
verses.text: Draw by your instruction those who are angry to friendship, and those who are at variance to agreement.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:29
verses.text: For the Lord says: "Blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called the children of God".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:30
verses.text: That the Judicatures of Christians Ought to Be Held on the Second Day of the Week.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:31
verses.text: XLVII.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:32
verses.text: Let your judicatures be held on the second day of the week, that if any controversy arise about your sentence, having an interval till the Sabbath, you may be able to set the controversy right, and to reduce those to peace who have the contests one with another against the Lord's day.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:33
verses.text: Let also the deacons and presbyters be present at your judicatures, to judge without acceptance of persons, as men of God, with righteousness.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:34
verses.text: When, therefore, both the parties are come, according as the law says, those that have the controversy shall stand severally in the middle of the court; and when you have heard them, give your votes holily, endeavouring to make them both friends before the sentence of the bishop, that judgment against the offender may not go abroad into the world; knowing that he has in the court the Christ of God as conscious of and confirming his judgment.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:35
verses.text: But if any persons are accused by any one, and their fame suffers as if they did not walk uprightly in the Lord, in like manner you shall hear both parties—the accuser and accused; but not with prejudice, nor with hearkening to one part only, but with righteousness, as passing a sentence concerning eternal life or death.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:36
verses.text: For says God: "He shall prosecute that which is right justly".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:37
verses.text: For he that is justly punished and separated by you is rejected from eternal life and glory; he becomes dishonourable among holy men, and one condemned of God.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:38
verses.text: That the Same Punishment is Not to Be Inflicted for Every Offence, But Different Punishments for Different Offenders.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:39
verses.text: XLVIII.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:40
verses.text: Do not pass the same sentence for every sin, but one suitable to each crime, distinguishing all the several sorts of offences with much prudence, the great from the little.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:41
verses.text: Treat a wicked action after one manner, and a wicked word after another; a bare intention still otherwise.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:42
verses.text: So also in the case of a contumely or suspicion.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:43
verses.text: And some thou shalt curb by threatenings alone; some thou shalt punish with fines to the poor; some thou shalt mortify with fastings; and others thou shalt separate according to the greatness of their several crimes.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:44
verses.text: For the law did not allot the same punishment to every offence, but had a different regard to a sin against God, against the priest, against the temple, or against the sacrifice; from a sin against the king, or ruler, or a soldier, or a fellow-subject; and so were the offences different which were against a servant, a possession, or a brute creature.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:45
verses.text: And again, sins were differently rated according as they were against parents and kinsmen, and those differently which were done on purpose from those that happened involuntarily.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:46
verses.text: Accordingly the punishments were different: as death either by crucifixion or by stoning, fines, scourgings, or the suffering the same mischiefs they had done to others.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:47
verses.text: Wherefore do you also allot different penalties to different offences, lest any injustice should happen, and provoke God to indignation.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:48
verses.text: For of what unjust judgment soever you are the instruments, of the same you shall receive the reward from God.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:49
verses.text: "For with what judgment ye judge ye shall be judged".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:50
verses.text: What are to Be the Characters of Accusers and Witnesses.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:51
verses.text: XLIX.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:52
verses.text: When, therefore, you are set down at your tribunal, and the parties are both of them present (for we will not call them brethren until they receive each other in peace), examine diligently concerning those who appear before you; and first concerning the accuser, whether this be the first person he has accused, or whether he has advanced accusations against some others before, and whether this contest and accusation of theirs does not arise from some quarrel, and what sort of life the accuser leads.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:53
verses.text: Yet, though he be of a good conscience, do not give credit to him alone, for that is contrary to the law; but let him have others to join in his testimony, and those of the same course of life.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:54
verses.text: As the law says: "At the mouth of two or three witnesses everything shall be established".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:55
verses.text: But why did we say that the character of the witnesses was to be inquired after, of what sort it is? Because it frequently happens that two and more testify for mischief, and with joint consent prefer a lie; as did the two elders against Susanna in Babylon, and the sons of transgressors against Naboth in Samaria, and the multitude of the Jews against our Lord at Jerusalem, and against Stephen His first martyr.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:56
verses.text: Let the witnesses therefore be meek, free from anger, full of equity, kind, prudent, continent, free from wickedness, faithful, religious; for the testimony of such persons is firm on account of their character, and true on account of their mode of life.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:57
verses.text: But as to those of a different character, do not ye receive their testimony, although they seem to agree together in their evidence against the accused; for it is ordained in the law: "Thou shalt not be with a multitude for wickedness; thou shalt not receive a vain report; thou shalt not consent with a multitude to pervert judgment".

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:58
verses.text: You ought also particularly to know him that is accused; what he is in his course and mode of life; whether he have a good report as to his life; whether he has been unblameable; whether he has been zealous in holiness; whether he be a lover of the widows, a lover of the strangers, a lover of the poor, and a lover of the brethren; whether he be not given to filthy lucre; whether he be not an extravagant person, or a spendthrift; whether he be sober, and free from luxury, or a drunkard, or a glutton; whether he be compassionate and charitable.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:59
verses.text: That Former Offences Do Sometimes Render After Accusations Credible.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:60
verses.text: L.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:61
verses.text: For if he has been before addicted to wicked works, the accusations which are now brought against him will thence in some measure appear to be true, unless justice do plainly plead for him.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:62
verses.text: For it may be, that though he had formerly been an offender, yet that he may not be guilty of this crime of which he is accused.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:63
verses.text: Wherefore be exactly cautious about such circumstances, and so render your sentences, when pronounced against the offender convicted, safe and firm.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:64
verses.text: And if, after his separation, he begs pardon, and falls down before the bishop, and acknowledges his fault, receive him.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:65
verses.text: But neither do you suffer a false accuser to go unpunished, that he may not calumniate another who lives well, or encourage some other person to do like him.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:66
verses.text: Nor, to be sure, do ye suffer a person convicted to go off clear, lest another be ensnared in the same crimes.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:67
verses.text: For neither shall a witness of mischiefs be unpunished, nor shall he that offends be without censure.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:68
verses.text: Against Judging Without Hearing Both Sides.

verses.name: Constitutions of the Holy Apostles Book II 6:69
verses.text: LI.
